Here’s everything I was able to pull together for you. Let me know if you need anything else or want me to dig further.

1) Recent Gmail appointment notes / threads that mention Ethan’s diagnosis, treatment plan, or return-to-school timeline  
• “Re: Ethan's Health and School Attendance” – sent by you to Mrs. Thompson (30 Jan 2022)  
  – Summary: You explained Ethan had a mild seasonal flu, was resting at home, and was expected back by Wed 2 Feb. No chronic-condition details were shared.  
  – Full text is still in your Sent folder under the subject above.  

• No other messages in Gmail explicitly summarize his Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) diagnosis or ongoing treatment. Everything related to that lives in Notion (see below). If you’ve had more recent email exchanges with Ethan’s parents or specialists that I missed, let me know a keyword and I’ll search again.

2) Notion pages & sections relevant to accommodations, restrictions, and follow-up  
• Page: “Ethan Davis – Medical Record”  
  – Key excerpts (NOT for direct disclosure to the school without consent):  
    • Diagnosis: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (rare neuromuscular disorder)  
    • Current treatment: daily deflazacort 0.9 mg/kg + weekly PT  
    • Note stressing strict privacy of detailed medical info  

• Page: “Ethan’s School Recommendations” (useful for Mrs. Thompson)  
  – General accommodations: extra time for assignments, access to a quiet rest space, ready access to water/snacks  
  – Activity restrictions: modified PE, availability of a scribe/note-taker during muscle-fatigue episodes  
  – Follow-up: suggests drafting a Personalized Education Plan (PEP); doesn’t disclose diagnosis specifics  

I can export or copy selected sections (e.g., only the recommendation bullets) if you want to paste them into the reply.

3) Consent / privacy requirements to mention  
• The Medical Record page reminds us: “Detailed medical information is not to be disclosed without explicit parental consent.”  
• Best practice:  
  – Share only functional needs and accommodations, not the name of the diagnosis or medication details.  
  – Reference the family’s standing consent (if one exists) or add a line such as, “Per the family’s authorization on file, I am providing the following classroom accommodations.”  
  – Offer to coordinate directly with parents for any further medical specifics.

I did not find a signed consent form in Gmail or Notion. If you have a scanned copy elsewhere, let me know; otherwise you might want to get a quick written release before sending details beyond accommodations.

4) Points / tone for the response (please confirm or adjust)  
• Supportive, collaborative, and concise—focus on how the school can help Ethan succeed.  
• Provide expected absence pattern (e.g., occasional fatigue-related absences) without labeling the exact condition.  
• Emphasize availability for follow-up questions and willingness to coordinate a PEP meeting.  
• Maintain HIPAA-conscious phrasing: “medical condition” or “health needs” instead of naming DMD, unless parents approve.

Next steps  
• Let me know which Notion excerpts you want copied verbatim.  
• Confirm whether we have parental consent on file or if we need to request it.  
• Tell me any tweaks to tone or emphasis, and I’ll draft the email for Mrs. Thompson right away.
